descriptions: Student demonstrates no understanding of rotations, reflections, or translations.
Student can identify rotations, reflections, or translations in isolation, but not in a sequence.
Student can identify rotations, reflections, and translations, but struggles to describe a sequence that maps one figure onto another.
Student can describe a sequence of transformations (rotations, reflections, translations) that maps one figure onto another with some errors.
Student can accurately describe a sequence of transformations (rotations, reflections, translations) that maps one figure onto another.
Student can accurately describe multiple sequences of transformations that map one figure onto another, demonstrating a deep understanding of congruence.
Student does not understand the concept of congruence in relation to transformations.
Student understands that congruent figures are the same size and shape, but cannot relate it to transformations.
Student can identify congruent figures and name transformations, but cannot link the two concepts together.
Student can explain how transformations can be used to prove congruence with some prompting.
Student can clearly explain how transformations can be used to prove congruence.
Student can apply transformations to prove congruence in complex geometric problems and explain the reasoning clearly.
Student uses inaccurate or unclear language when describing transformations and congruence.
Student uses vague language when describing transformations and congruence.
Student uses generally correct language, but lacks precision in describing specific transformations.
Student uses precise language to describe transformations and congruence most of the time.
Student consistently uses precise language to accurately describe transformations and congruence.
Student consistently uses precise and sophisticated language to explain transformations and congruence in a way that enhances understanding.
